Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old gentleman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and previous cerebrovascular accident (CVA) who presented with left lower lobe pneumonia. He was transferred to the MICU for hypoxia and is currently on invasive ventilation. 

The patient's recent CD4 count is 442, indicating well-controlled HIV infection, and his viral load is undetectable. He has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent CABG in the past. 

His current vital signs show a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, blood pressure of 101/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93% on 80% FiO2. 

The patient has been diagnosed with chronic diastolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 40%. He appears euvolemic and there are concerns about an acute exacerbation in the setting of infection. 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate a pH of 7.38, PaCO2 of 56 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 115. 

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.6 K/uL, hemoglobin of 12.9 g/dL, sodium of 139 mg/dL, potassium of 4.2 mEq/L, creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL, and troponin-T of <0.01 ng/mL. 

The patient's chest X-ray reveals bibasilar opacification, bilateral pleural effusions, and interstitial prominence. 

The patient's respiratory viral antigen screen came back uninterpretable due to lack of cells, but the bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid gram stain showed 1+ polymorphonuclear leukocytes and no microorganisms seen. 

The patient's plan includes continuing vancomycin, cefepime, and Flagyl to cover for hospital-acquired pneumonia and aspiration pneumonia. They will also obtain an echo, trend chest X-ray, cardiac enzymes, and continue ARDSnet protocol. Blood cultures have been obtained, and consideration is being given to repeating the bronchoscopic evaluation. 

In terms of HIV management, the patient's home regimen of ritonavir and saquinavir will be continued, but with liquid ritonavir given through oral-gastric tube and breaking up saquinavir capsule to give through OG. The patient's ID consultation is pending due to lack of clear improvement during this time. 

Other ongoing issues include chronic diastolic heart failure, coronary artery disease (post-CABG), hypertension, and hepatitis C. 

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is pending clinical improvement.
